div.head: The Prologue at the black Friers.
div.p:
THey that feare the flinging of Waspes make fannes of Peacokes tailes, whose spots are like eies. And Lepidus, which coulde not sleepe for the chattinge of birdes, set vp a beaste, whose head was like a Dragon: and we which stande in awe of reporte, are compelled to sette beefore our owle Pallas shield, thinking by her vertue to couer the others deformitie. It was a signe of famine to Aegypte, when Nylus flowed lesse then twelue Cubittes, or more then eighteene, and it may threaten dispaire vnto vs, if wee be lesse curious then you looke for, or more cumbersome. But as Theseus being promised to bee brought to an Eagles neast, and trauailing all the day, found but a wrenne in a hedg, yet said, this is a bird: so we hope, if the shower of our swelling mountaine seeme to bring forth some Eliphant, perfourme but a mouse, you will gently saye, this is a beast? Basill softly touched, yeeldeth a sweete sent, but chafed in the hande, a ranke sauour. Wee feare euen so that our labours slylye glaunced on, will breede some content, but examined to the proofe, small commendation. The haste in perfourming shall be our excuse, There went two nightes to the begetting of Hercules. Feathers appeare not on the Phoenix vnder seauen monethes, and the Mulbery is twelue in buddinge, but our trauailes are like the Hares, who at one time bringeth forth, nourisheth, and engendreth againe, or like the broode of Trasbylus, whose egges in the same moment
that they are layd, become birdes. But howsoeuer we finish our worke, we craue pardon, if we offend in matter, and patience if we transgresse in manners. Wee haue mixed mirth with counsell, and discipline with delight, thinking it not amisse in the same garden to sowe pot-hearbes, that we set flowers. But wee hope, as Harts that cast their hornes, Snakes their skinnes, Eagles their bils, become more fresh for any other labour: so our charge being shaken off, we shalbe fitte for greater matters. But least like the Mindyans, we make our gates greater then our towne, and that our play runnes out at the preface, we here conclude: wishing that although there bee in your precise iudgementes an vniuersall mislike, yet wee maye enjoy by your woonted curtesies a generall silence.

div.head: The Prologue at the Court.
div.p: WEe are ashamed that our birde, which fluttered by twilight seeming a Swan, should be proued a Batte sette against the sunne. But as Iupiter placed Silenus Asse among the starres, and Alcebiades couered his pictures being Owles and Apes, with a courtaine embroidered with Lyons and Eagles, so are we enforced vpon a rough discourse to draw on a smooth excuse, resbling Lapidaries, who thinke to hide the cracke in a stone by setting it deepe in golde. The Gods supped once with poore Baucis, the Persian kinges sometimes shaued stickes, our hope is your heighnesse will at this time lend an eare to an idle pastime. Appion raising Homere from hell, demanded onely who was his father, and we calling Alexander from his graue, seeke onely who was his loue. Whatsoeuer we present, we wish it may be thought the daunsing of Agrippa his shadowes, who in the moment they were seene, were of any shape one woulde conceiue: or Lynces, who hauing a quicke fight to discerne, haue a short memorie to forgette. With vs it is like to fare, as with these torches, which giuing light to others, consume themselues, and wee shewing delight to others, shame our selues.

div.head: Actus primus, Scaena prima.
div.stage: Clitus, Parmenio, Timoclea, Campaspe, Alexander, Hephestion.

sp.speaker: Clyt.
sp.p: PArmenio, I cannot tel whether I should more commend in Alexanders victories, courage, or curtesie, in the one being a resolution without feare, in the other a liberalitie aboue custome: Thebes is raysed, the people not racked, towers throwne down, bodies not thrust aside, a conquest without conflict, and a cruell warre in a milde peace.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Clytus, it becommeth the sonne of Phillip to be none other then Alexander is: therefore seeing in the father a full perfection, who could haue doubted in the sonne an excellencie. For as the moone can borrow nothing els of the sunne but light, so of a fire, in whome nothing but vertue was, what coulde the childe receiue but singuler? It is for Turkes to staine each other, not for diamond, in the one to bee made a difference in goodnes, in the other no comparison.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.p: You mistake mee Parmenio, if whilest I commend Alexander, you imagine I call Phillyp into question, vnlesse happely you coniecture (which none of iudgment will conceiue) that because I like the fruit, therefore I heaue at the tree, or coueting to kisse the childe, I therefore goe about to poyson the teat.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: I but Clytus I perceiue you are borne in the East, and neuer laugh but at the sunne rising, which argueth though a duetie where you ought, yet no great deuotion where you might.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p:
We wil make no controuersie of that which there ought to be no question, onely this shal be the opinion
of vs both, that none was worthy to be the father of Alexander but Phillip, nor any meete to bee the sonne of Phillip but Alexander.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Soft Clytus, behold the spoiles & prisoners, a pleasaunt sight to vs, because profit is ioyned with honour, not much paineful to them, because their captiuitie is eased by mercy.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Fortune, thou didst neuer yet deceiue vertue, because vertue neuer yet did trust fortune. Sworde and fire will neuer get spoile, where wisdome and fortitude beares sway. O Thebes, thy walles were raysed by the sweetenesse of the harpe, but rased by the shrilnes of the trumpet. Alexander had neuer come so neere the wals, had Epaminondas walkt about the walles, and yet might the Thebanes haue beene mery in their streetes, if he had beene to watch their towers. But destinie is seldome foreseene, neuer preuented. We are heere now captiues, whose neckes are yoaked by force, but whose hearts can not yeelde by death. Come Campaspe and the rest, let vs not be ashamed to cast our eies on him, on whome wee feared not to cast our dartes.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Madame, you neede not doubt, it is Alexander, that is, the conquerour.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Alexander hath ouercome, not conquered.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.p: To bring al vnder his subiection is to conquer.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: He cannot subdue that which is diuine.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Thebes was not.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Vertue is.

sp.speaker: Clytus.
sp.p: Alexander as hee tendreth vertue, so hee will you, he drinketh not bloud, but thirsteth after honor, he is greedy of victory, but neuer satisfied with mercie. In fight terrible, as beecommeth a captaine, in conqueste milde, as beseemeth a king. In al things then which nothing can be greater he is Alexander.

sp.speaker: Campas.
sp.p:
Then if it be such a thing to be Alexander, I hope it shalbe no miserable thing to be a virgin. For if
he saue our honors, it is more than; to restore our goodes. And rather doe I wishe hee preserue our fame then our lyues, which if he do, wee will confesse there can bee no greater thing then to be Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Clytus, are these prisoners? of whence these spoiles?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: Like your maiestie they are prisoners, & of Thebes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Of what calling or reputation?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.p: I know not, but they seeme to be Ladies of honor.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I wil know: Madam, of whence you are I know, but who, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.p: Alexander, I am the sister of Theagines, whoe fought a battle with thy father, before the Citie of Chyeronie, where he died, I say which none can gainsay, valiāly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Lady, there seeme in your wordes sparkes of your brothers deedes, but woorser fortune in your lyfe then his death: but feare not, for you shall liue without violence, enemies, or necessitie: but what are you fayre Lady, an other sister to Theagines?

sp.speaker: Campas.
sp.p: No sister to Theagines, but an humble handmaid to Alexander, borne of a meane parentage, but to extreame fortune.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well Ladies, for so your vertues shewe you, whatsoeuer your birthes be, you shalbe honourably entreated. Athens shalbe your Thebes, & you shall not be as abiectes of warre, but as subiectes to Alexander. Parmenio, conducte these honourable Ladies into the Citie, charge the souldiers not so much as in wordes to offer them any offence, and let all wants be supplyed so farre forth as shalbe necessary for such persons and my prisoners.

Hephestion, it resteth now that we haue as great care to gouerne in peace, as conquer in war: that whilest armes cease, Artes may flourish, and ioyning letters with launces we endeuor to be as good Philosophers as soldiers, knowing it no lesse praise to be wise, than commendable to be valiaunt.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Your Maiestie therein sheweth that you haue as great desire to rule as to subdue: & needes must that common wealth be fortunate, whose Captaine is a Philosopher, and whose Philosopher is a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: I serue in steede of a maister, a mouse, whose house is a tub, whose dinner is a crust, and whose boord is a bed.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Then art thou in a state of life, which Philosophers commend. A crumme for thy supper, an hande for thy cup, and thy clothes for thy sheetes. For Natura paucis contenta.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Manes, it is pittie so proper a man should be cast away vppon a Philosopher: but that Diogines that dogge should haue Manes that dogbolte, it greeueth nature and spiteth arte: the one hauing found the so dissolute, absolute I would say, in body, the other so single singuler in minde.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Are you mery, it is a signe by the trip of your tongue, and the toyes of your heade, that you haue done that to day, which I haue not done these three daies.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Dined.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: I thinke Diogines keepes but cold cheere.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I would it were so, but hee keepeth neither hot nor cold.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What then, luke warme? That made Manes runne from his maister last day.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Manes had reason: for his name foretolde as much.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: My name? how so sir boy?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: You know that it is called Mons, à mouendo, because it standes still.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: And thou art named Manes, à manendo, beecause thou runst away.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Passing reasons, I did not runne awaye, but retire.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: To a prison, because thou wouldest haue leasure to contemplate.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I will proue that my body was immortall: because it was in prison.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Did your maisters neuer teache you that the soule is immortal?

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: And the body is the prison of the soule.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Why then, thus to make my body immortall, I put it to prison.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Oh bad.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Excellent ill.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: You may see how dull a fasting wit is: therefore Psyllus let vs go to supper with Granichus: Plato is the best fellow of al Phylosophers. Giue me him that reades in the morning in the schoole, and at noone in the kitchin.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: And me.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Ah sirs, my maister is a king in his parlour for the body, & a God in his study for the soule. Among all his menne he commendeth one that is an excellente Musition, then stand I by and clap another on the shoulder and say, this is a passing good Cooke.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: It is well doone Granichus, for giue me pleasure that goes in at the mouth, not the eare, I had rather fill my guttes, then my braines.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p:
I serue Apelles, who feedeth mee, as Diogenes
dooth Manes, for at dinner the one preacheth abstinence, the other commendeth counterfeiting: when I would eat meate, he paintes a spit, & when I thirst, O faith he, is not this a faire pot, and pointes to a table, whiche conteines the banquet of the Gods, where are many dishes to feede the eie, but not to fill the gut.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What doost thou then?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: This doth hee then bring in many examples that some haue liued by fauours, & proueth that muche easier it is to fatte by colours, and telles of birdes that haue beene fatted by painted grapes in winter: & howe many haue so fed their eies with their mistresse picture, that they neuer desired to take food, being glutted with the delight in their fauours. Then doth he shew me counterfeites, such as haue furfeited with their filthy & lothsome vomites, and with the riotous Bacchanalles of the God Bacchus, and his disorderly crew, which are painted al to the life in his shop. To conclude, I fare hardly, thogh I go richly, which maketh me when I shuld begin to shadow a Ladies face, to draw a Lambes head, and somtime to set to the body of a maide a shoulder of mutton: for semper animus meus est in patinis.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Thou art a God to me: for could I see but a Cookes shop painted, I woulde make mine eyes fatte as butter. For I haue nought but sentences to fill my maw, as, plures occidit crapula quàm gladius: musateiunantibus amica: repletion killeth delicately: & an old saw of abstinence, Socrates: The belly is the heades graue. Thus with sayings not with meate he maketh a gallymafrey.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: But how doest thou then liue?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: With fine iests, sweet aire, & the dogs almes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Wel, for this time I wil stanch thy gut, and among pots and platters thou shalt see what it is to serue Plato.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: For ioy of Granichus lets sing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: My voice is as clear in the euening as in the morning.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: An other commoditie of emptines.

div.head: Actus primus, Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Melippus, Plato, Aristotle, Crisippus, Crates, Cleanthes, Anaxarchus, Alexander, Hephestion Parmenio, Clytus, Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Melip.
sp.p: I had neuer such adoe to warne schollers to come before a king: First, I came to Crisippus a tall leane old mad man, willing him presently to appeare before Alexander, he stoode staring on my face, neither mouing his eies nor his body, I vrging him to giue some answer, hee tooke vp a booke, sate downe and saide nothing: Melissa his maid told mee it was his maner, and that oftentimes she was fain to thrust meate in to his mouth: for that he wold rather starue than ceasse studie. Wel thoght I, seeing bookish men are so blockish, & so great clearkes such simple courtiers, I will neither be partaker of their commons nor their commendations. From thence I came to Plato and to Aristotle, and to diuerse other none refusing to come, sauing an old obscure fellowe, who sitting in a tub turned towardes the sonne, read Greek to a young boy, him when I willed to appeare before Alexander, he answered, if Alexander would faine see me, let him come to me, if learne of mee, lette him come to me, whatsoeuer it be, let him come to me: why, said I, he is a king, hee answered, why I am a Philosopher, why, but he is Alexander, I but I am Diogenes. I was halfe angry to see one so crooked in his shape, to be so crabbed in his sayinges. So going my way, I said thou shalt repent it, if thou commest not to Alexander: nay, smiling answered hee, Alexander may repent it, if he come not to Diogenes: vertue must be sought, not offered: and so turning himself to his cell, he grunted I know not what, like a pig vnder a tub. But I must be gone, the Philosophers are comming.

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: It is a difficult controuersie, Aristotle, and rather to be wondred at, then beleeued, how naturall causes should worke supernal effects.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: I doe not so much stand vpon the apparition is seene in the Moone, neither the Demonium of Socrates, as that I cannot by naturall reason giue anye reason of the ebbing and flowing of the Sea, which makes mee in the depth of my studies to crye out, O ens entium miserere mei.

sp.speaker: Plato.
sp.p: Cleanthes, and you attribute so muche to nature by searching for things which are not to be found, that whilest you studie a cause of your owne, you omitte the occasion it selfe. There is no man so sauage in whom resteth not this diuine particle, that there is an omnipotent, eternall and diuine mouer, which may be called God.

sp.speaker: Cleant.
sp.p: I am of this minde, that that firste moouer, which you tearme God, is the instrument of all the mouinges, which we attribute to nature. The earth which is masse, swimmeth on the sea, seasons deuided in themselues, fruites growing in themselues, the maiestie of the skie, the whole firmament of the world, and whatsoeuer els appeareth miraculous, what man almoste of meane capacitie but can proue it naturall.

sp.speaker: Anaxar
sp.p: These causes shalbe debated at our Philosophers feast, in which controuersie I will take parte with Aristotle, that there is Naturanaturans, and yet not God.

sp.speaker: Craterus
sp.p: And I with Plato, that there is Deus optimus maximus, and not nature.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: Here commeth Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I see Hephestion, that these Philosophers are here attending for vs.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: They were not Philosophers, if they knewe not their dueties.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But I much meruaile Diogenes shoulde bee so dogged.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: I do not think but his excuse wil be better then Melippus message.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I wil go see him Hephestion, because I long to see him that would commaunde Alexander to come, to whom all the world is like to come. Aristotle & the reste sithence my comming from Thebes to Athens, from a place of conqueste to a pallace of quiet, I haue resolued with my self in my court to haue as many Philosophers as I had in my camp soldiers. My court shalbe a schoole, wherein I wil haue vsed as great doctrine in peace, as I did in warre discipline.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: We are al here ready to be commanded, & glad we are that we are commanded, for that nothing better becommeth kinges then literature, which maketh them come as neere to the Gods in wisdome, as they doe in dignitie.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is so Aristotle, but yet there is among you, yea & of your bringing vp, that sought to destroy Alexander, Calistenes, Aristotle, whose treasons againste his prince shall not bee borne out with the reasons of his Phylosophy.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: If euer mischiefe entred into the hearte of Calistenes, let Calistenes suffer for it, but that Aristotle euer imagined any such thing of Calistenes, Aristotle doth denie.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well Aristotle, kindred may blind thee, and affection mee, but in kinges causes I will not stande to schollers arguments. This meeting shalbe for a commandement, that you all frequente my courte, instructe the young with rules, confirme the olde with reasons: lette your liues be answerable to your learninges, leaste my proceedinges be contrary to my promises.

sp.speaker: Hophest.
sp.p: You sayde you woulde aske euerye one of them a question, which yester night none of vs could aunswere.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I will. Plato, of all beastes, which is the subtillest?

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: That which man hetherto neuer knew.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Aristotle, how should a man bee thought a God?

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: In doing a thing vnpossible for a man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Crisyppus, which was first, the day or the night?

sp.speaker: Crisip.
sp.p: The day by a day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In deede straunge questions must haue straung answers, Cleanthes, what say you, is life or death the stronger?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Life, that suffereth so many troubles.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Crates, how long should a man liue?

sp.speaker: Crates
sp.p: Till he think it better to die then liue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Anaxarchus, whether doth the sea or the earth bring forth most creatures?

sp.speaker: Anax.
sp.p: The earth, for the sea is but a parte of the earth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hephestion, me thinkes they haue answered all well, and in such questions I meane often to trye them.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: It is better to haue in your court a wise manne, then in your ground a golden mine. Therefore would I leane war, to studie wisdome, were I Alexander.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So would I, were I Hephestion. But come let vs go and giue release, as I promised to our Theban thralles.

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: Thou art fortunate Aristotle, that Alexander is thy scholler.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: And all you happy that he is your souereigne.

sp.speaker: Crisip.
sp.p: I could like the man well, if he could be contented to be but a man.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: He seeketh to draw neere to the Gods in knowledge, not to be a God.

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: Let vs question a litle with Diogines, why he went not with vs to Alexander, Diogenes, thou didst forget thy duetie, that thou wentst not with vs to the king.

sp.speaker: Dioge.
sp.p: And you your profession, that you went to the king.

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: Thou takest as great pride to be peeuish, as others do glory to be vertuous.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou as great honor being a Philosopher to be thought courtlike, as others shame that be courtiers, to be accounted Philosophers.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: These austere maners set aside, it is wel known that thou didst counterfeit money.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou thy manners, in that thou didst not counterfeit money.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: Thou hast reason to contemn the court, being both in bodye and minde too crooked for a courtier.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: As good bee crooked, and endeuour to make my selfe straight from the court, as to bee straighte, and learne to be crooked at the court.

sp.speaker: Crates
sp.p: Thou thinkest it a grace to be opposite against Alexander.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And thou to be iumpe with Alexander.

sp.speaker: Anaxar
sp.p: Let vs goe: for in cotemning him, we shal better please him, then in wondring at him.

sp.speaker: Arist.
sp.p: Plato, what doest thou thinke of Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Plato
sp.p: To be Socrates furious, let vs goe.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Behold Manes where thy maister is, seeking either for bones for his dinner, or pinnes for his sleeues. I will goe salute him.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Doe so, but mum not a word that you sawe Manes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Then staye thou behinde, and I will goe with Psyllus.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: All hayle Diogenes to your proper person.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: All hate to thy peeuish conditions.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: O Dogge.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: What dost thou seeke for here?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: For a man and a beast.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: That is easie without thy light to be founde, be not all these men?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Called men.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What beast is it thou lookest for?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The beast my man Manes.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: He is a beast in deede that wil serue thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: So is he that begat thee.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: What wouldest thou do, if thou shuldest finde Manes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Giue him leaue to doe as hee hath done beefore.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To runne away.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why, hast thou no neede of Manes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It were a shame for Diogenes to haue neede of Manes, and for Manes to haue no neede of Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: But put the case he were gone, wouldst thou entertaine any of vs two?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Vppon condition.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That you should tell mee wherefore anye of you both were good.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, I am a scholler, and well seene in Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: And I a prentice, and well seene in paynting.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Well then Granichus, be thou a painter to amende thine ill face, and thou Psyllus a Philosopher to correct thine euil manners. But who is that Manes?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I care not whoe I were so I were not Manes.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: You are taken tardie.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Let vs slip aside Grauickiis, to see the salutation betweene Manes and his maister.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Manes, thou knowest the last daye I threw away my dish to drink in my hand, because it was superfluous, now I am determined to put away my man, and serue my selfe: Quia non egeo tui velte.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Maister, you know a while agoe I ran away, so doe I meane to doe againe, quia'scio tibi esse argentum.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I know I haue no money, neither will I haue euer a man: for I was resolued long sithence to put away both my slaues, money and Maues.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: So was I determined to shake off both my dogges, hunger and Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: O sweete concent betweene a crowde and a Iewes harpe.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Come, let vs reconcile them

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: It shal not neede: for this is their vse, now do they dine one vpon another.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: How nowe Manes, art thou gone from thy mayster.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: No, I didde but nowe binde my selfe to him.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why, you were at mortalliars.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: In faith no, we brake a bitter iest one vppon another.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, thou art as dogged as he.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: My father knew them both litle whelpes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Well, I wil hie me after my maister.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Why, is it supper time with Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I, with him at al times when he hath meate.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why then euerye man to his home, and let vs steale out againe anon.

sp.speaker: Grani.
sp.p: Where shall we meete.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why, at Ala vendibili suspensa badera non est epus.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: O Psyllus habeo te leco parentis, thou blessest me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Stand aside sir boy, till you bee called. Hephestion, how doe yee like the sweete face of Campaspe?

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: I cannot but commend the stout courage of Timeclea.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Without doubt Campaspe had som great man to her father.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: You know Timoclea had Theagines to her brother.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Timoclea stil in thy mouth, art thou not in loue?

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Not with Timoclea you meane, wherein you resemble the Lapwing, who crieth most where her neast is not. And so you lead me from espying your loue with Campaspe, you cry Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Coulde I aswell subdue kingdomes, as I can my thoughtes, or were I as farre from ambition, as I am from loue, all the world would account me as valiaunt in armes as I know my self moderate in affection.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Is loue a vice?

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: It is no vertue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Well, nowe shalt thou see what small difference I make betweene Alexander and Hephestion. And sith thou hast beene alwaies partaker of my triumphes, thou shalt be partaker of my tormentes. I loue Hephestion, I loue I loue Campaspe, a thing farre vnfit for a Macedonian, for a king, for Alexander. Whye hangest thou downe thy head Hephestion? blushing to hear that which
I am not ashamed to tell.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Might my wordes craue pardon and my counsell credit, I woulde both discharge the duetie of a subiect, for so I am, and the office of a friend, for so I wil.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Speake Hephestion, for whatsoeuer is spoken, Hephestion speaketh to Alexander.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p:
I cannot tell Alexander, whether the reporte be more shamefull to be heard, or the cause sorowfull to be beleeued? What, is the sonne of Phillip, king of Macedon become the subiect of Campaspe, the captiue of Thebes? Is that minde, whose greatnes the world coulde not containe, drawn within the compasse of an idle alluring eie? Wil you handle the spindle with Hercules, when you shuld shake the speare with Achilles? Is the warlike sound of drumme and trumpe turned to the softe noyse of lire and lute, the neighing of barbed steedes, whose loudnes filled the ayre with terrour, and whose breathes dimmed the sunne with smoake, conuerted to delicate tunes and amorous glaunces? O Alexander, that soft and yeelding minde should not bee in him, whose hard and vnconquered heart hath made so many yeelde. But you loue, ah griefe, but whom? Campaspe, ah shame, a maide forsooth vnknowne, vnnoble; and who can tell whether immodest? whose eies are framed by arte to inamour, and whose heart was made by nature to enchaunt. I, but she is bewtiful, yea, but not therefore chaste: I, but she is comly in al partes of the body: yea, but she may be crooked in some parte of the mind; I, but she is wise, yea, but she is a woman: Bewtie is like the blackberry, which seemeth red, when it is not ripe resembling pretious stones that are polished with honney, which the smother they look, the sooner they breake. It is thought wonderful among the sea men that Mugil of all fishes the swifteste is found in the belly of the Bret of all the slowest; And shal it not seeme monstrous to wise men, that the hearte of the greatest conquerour of the worlde, should be found
in the handes of the weakest creature of nature? of a woman? of a captiue? Hermyns haue faire skinnes, but fowle liuers; Sepulcher's fresh colours but rotten bones, women faire faces, but false heartes. Remember Alexander thou haste a campe to gouerne, not a chamber, fall not from the armour of Mars to the armes of Venus, from the fiery assaults of warre, to the maidenly skirmishes of loue from displaying the Eagle in thine ensigne, to sette downe the sparrow. I sigh Alexander that where fortune could not counquer, folly should ouercome. But behold al the perfection that may be in Campaspe, a haire curling by nature, not arte: sweete alluring eies, a faire face made in despite of Venus; and a stately porte in disdaine of Iuno, a witte apt to conceaue, and quick to aunswere a skin as softe as silke, and as smooth as iet, a long white hand, a fine little foote, to conclude, all partes aunswerable to the best part, what of this? Though she haue heauenlye gifts, vertue and bewtie, is she not of earthly mettal flesh and bloud? You Alexander that would be a God, shewe your self in this worse then a man, so soone to bee both ouerseene and ouertaken in a woman, whose false teares know their true times, whose smooth wordes wounde deeper then sharpe swordes. There is no surfeit so dangerous, as that of honeye, nor any poyson so deadly, as that of loue, in the one phisicke cannot preuaile, nor in the other counsel.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
My case were light Hephestion, and not worthy to be called loue, if reason were a remedie, or sentenses could salue, that sense cannot conceaue, Litle do you know, and therefore sleightly doe you regard the dead embers in a priuate perso, or liue coles in a great prince, whose passions and thoughts do as farre exceede others in extremitie, as their callinges doe in Maiestie. An Eclipse in the Sunne is more then the fallinge of a starre, none can conceiue the tormentes of a king, vnlesse hee be a king; whose desires are not inferiour to their dignities.
And then iudge Hephestion if the agonies of loue be dangerous in a subiect, whether they be not more then deadly vnto Alexander, whose deep and not to be conceiued sighes, cleaue the heart in shiuers, whose wounded thoughtes can neither be expressed nor endured. Cease then Hephestion with argumentes to seeke to refel that, which with their deitie the Gods cannot resist, and let this suffice to aunswere thee, that it is a king that loueth and Alexander, whose affections are not to be measured by reason, being immortall, nor I feare me to bee borne being intollerable.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: I must needes yeeld, when neither reason nor counsel can be heard.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yeelde Hephestion, for Alexander doth loue, & therefore must obtaine.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Suppose she loues not you, affection commeth not by appointmente or birth, and then as good hated as enforced.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I am a king, and wil commaund.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: You may, to yeelde to luste by force, but to consent to loue by feare you cannot.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, what is that, which Alexander maye not conquer as he list?

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Why, that which you say the Gods cannot resiste, Loue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I am a conquerour, shee a captiue, I as fortunate, as she faire: my greatnes may answere her wants, and the giftes of my minde, the modestie of hers: Is it not likely then that shee should loue? Is it not reasonable?

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: You say that in loue there is no reason, and therefore there can be no likelyhood.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
No more Hephestion: in this case I wil vse mine owne counsell, and in all other thine aduice, thou mayst be a good soldier, but neuer good louer. Call my page. Sirha, goe presentlye to Apelles, and will him to come to
me without either delay or excuse.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I goe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In the meane season to recreate my spirits, being so neere, we will goe see Diogenes. And see where his tub is, Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Who calleth?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Alexander: how happened it that you woulde not come out of your tub to my pallace?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Because it was as far from my tub to your pallace, as from your pallace to my tub.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why then doest thou ow no reuerence to kings?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Because they be no Gods.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: They be Gods of the earth.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Yea, Gods of earth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Plato is not of thy mind.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Because I would haue none of Diogenes minde, but Diogenes

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If Alexander haue any thing that may pleasure Diogenes, let me know, and take it.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Then take not from me, that you cannot giue me, the light of the world.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What dost thou want?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nothing that you haue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I haue the world at commaund.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I in contempt.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thou shalt liue no longer then I will.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But I shall die whether you wil or no.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: How should one learne to be content?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Vnlearne to couet.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hephestion, were I not Alexander, I would wishe to be Diogenes.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p:
He is dogged, but discrete, I cannot tell how
sharpe with a kinde of sweetenes, full of wit, yet too to wayward.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Diogenes, when I come this way again, I wil both see thee, and confer with thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Doe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But here commeth Apelles, how now Apelles, is Venus face yet finished?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Not yet: Bewtie is not so soone shadowed, whose perfection commeth not within the compasse either of cunning or of colour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wel let it rest vnperfect, & come you with mee, where I will shewe you that finished by nature, that you haue beene trifling about by arte.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Lady, I doubt whether there bee any colour so fresh, that may shadow a countenance so faire.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Sir, I had thought you had beene commaunded to paint with your hand, not to glose with your tongue, but as I haue heard, it is the hardest thing in painting to set down a hard fauour, which maketh you to dispair of my face, and then shal you haue as great thanks to spare your labour, as to discredit your arte.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Mistresse, you neither differ from your selfe nor your sex: for knowing your own perfection, you seeme to dispraise that which men moste commend, drawing them by that meane into an admiration, where feedinge themselues they fal into an extasie, your modestie being the cause of the one, and of the other, your affections.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I am too young to vnderstande your speache, thogh old enough to withstand your deuise: you haue bin so long vsed to colours, you can do nothing but colour.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p:
Indeed the colours I see, I feare, wil altar the colour I haue: but come Madam, wil you draw neere: for
Alexander will be here anon. Psyllus, stay you heere at the window, if anye enquire for me, aunswere, Non lubet esse domi.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: It is alwaies my maisters fashion, when any fair gentlewoman is to be drawne within, to make mee to stay without. But if he shuld paint Iupiter like a Bul, like a Swanne like an Eagle, then must Psyllus with one hand grinde colours, and with the other hold the candle. But let him alone, the better he shadowes her face, the more will he burne his own heart. And now if a manne coulde meere with Manes, who I dare say, lookes as leane, as if Diogenes dropped out of his nose.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: And heere comes Manes, whoe hath as muche meate in his maw, as thou hast honestie in thy head.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Then I hope thou art very hungry.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: They that know thee, know that.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: But doest thou not remember that wee haue certeine licour to conferre withal.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I, but I haue busines, I must go cry a thing.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why, what hast thou lost?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: That which I neuer had, my dinner?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Foule lubber wilt thou crie for thy dinner?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I meane, I must cry, not as one wold saye cry, but cry, that is, make a noyse.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Why foole, that is all one, for if thou cry, thou must needes make a noise.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Boy, thou art deceiued Cry hath diuerse significations, and may bee alluded to manye thinges, knaue but one, and can be applyed but to thee.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Profound Manes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p:
Wee Cynickes are madde fellowes, didste thou
not finde I did quip thee?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: No verely, why, whats a quip?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: We great girders call it a short saying of a sharp witte, with a bitter sense in a sweete word.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: How canst thou thus diuine, deuide, define, dispute, and all on the sodaine?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Wit wil haue his swing, I am bewitcht, inspirde, inflamed, infected.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Well, then will not I tempt thy gybing spirite.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Do not Psyllus, for thy dull head will bee but a grindstone for my quick wit, which if thou whet with ouertwhartes, peristi, actum est de te. I haue drawne bloud at ones braines with a bitter bob.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Let me crosse my self: for I die, if I crosse thee.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Let me do my busines, I my self am afraid, least my wit should waxe warm, and then must it needes consume some hard head with fine & prety iests. I am sometimes in such a vaine, that for want of some dull pate to worke on, I begin to gird my selfe.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: The Gods shield mee from such a fine fellowe, whose words melt wits like waxe.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Well then, let vs to the matter. In fayth my maister meaneth tomorow to flye.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: It is a iest.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Is it a iest to flye? shouldest thou flye so soone, thou shouldest repent it in earnest.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Well, I will be the cryer.

sp.speaker: Man. and Psyl. one after another.
sp.p: O ys, o ys, o ys, All manner of men, women, or children, that wil come to morow into the market place, betweene the houres of nine and ten, shall see Diogenes the Cynick fly.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: I do not think he wil flye.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Tush, say fly.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Fly.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Now let vs goe: for I wil not see him againe, till midnight, I haue a back way into his tub.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Which way callest thou the backwaye, when euery way is open.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: I meane to come in at his back.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Well, let vs goe away, that we may returne speedely.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I shall neuer drawe your eies well, because they blind mine.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Why then, paint me without eies, for I am blind?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Were you euer shadowed before of any?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: No. And would you could so nowe shadow me, that I might not be perceiued of any.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It were pittie, but that so absolute a face should furnish Venus temple amongst these pictures.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What are these pictures?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Laeda, whom Ioue deceiued in likenes of a swan.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: A faire woman, but a foule deceit.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Alcmena, vnto whom Iupiter came in shape of Amphitrion her husband, and begate Hercules.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: A famous sonne, but an infamous fact.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: He might do it, because he was a God.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Nay, therefore it was euil done, because he was a God.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Danae, into whose prison Iupiter drisled a golden shewre, and obtained his desire.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What gold can make one yeelde to desire?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Europa, whom Iupiter rauished, this Antiopa.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Were al the Gods like this Iupiter?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: There were many Gods in this like Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p:
I thinke in those daies loue was well ratified among
men on earth, when lust was so full autorised by the Gods in heauen.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Nay, you may imagine there were women passing amiable, when ther were Gods exceding amorous.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Were women neuer so faire, men would be false.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Were women neuer so false, men wold be fond.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What counterfeit is this Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is Venus, the Goddesse of loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What, be there also louing Goddesses?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: This is she that hath power to commaunde the very affections of the heart.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How is she hired, by praier, by sacrifice, or bribs?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: By praier, sacrifice and bribes.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What praier?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Vowes irreuocable.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What sacrifice?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Hearts euer sighing, neuer dissembling.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What bribes?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Roses and kisses? but were you neuer in loue?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: No, nor loue in me.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Then haue you iniuried many.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Because you haue beene loued of many.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Flattered perchance of some.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Is it not possible that a face so faire, and a wit so sharp, both without comparison, shulde not bee apte to loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: If you begin to tip your tong with cunninge, I pray dip your pensil in colours, and fall to that you must doe, not that you would doe.

div.head: Actus tertius, Schaena quarta.
div.stage: Clytus, Parmenio, Alexander, Hephestion, Crysus, Diogenes, Apelles, Campaspe.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p:
Parmenio I cannot tell howe it commeth to passe, that in Alexander now a daies there groweth an vnpacient kinde of life, in the morning he is melancholye, at noone
solomne, at all times either more sower or seuere, then he was accustomed.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: In kinges causes I rather loue to doubte then coniecture and thinke it better to be ignoraunt then inquisitiue: they haue long eares and stretched armes, in whose heades suspition is a proofe, and to bee accused is to be condemned.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p: Yet betweene vs there canne be no daunger to finde out the cause: for that there is no malice to withstand it. It may be an vnquenchable thirste of conquering maketh him vnquiet: it is not vnlikely his long ease hath altred his humour: that hee shoulde be in loue, it is not impossible.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: In loue Clytus, no, no, it is as farre from his thought, as treason in ours: hee, whose euer waking eye, whose neuer tired heart, whose body pacient of labour, whose mind vnsatiable of victorie hath alwaies bin noted, cannot so soone be melted into the weake conceites of loue: Aristotle told him there were many worlds, and that he hath not conquered one that gapeth for all, galleth Alexander. But here he commeth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Parmenio, and Clitus, I would haue you both redy to goe into Persia about an ambassage no lesse profitable to me, then to your selues honourable.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.p: We are ready at all commaundes, wishing nothing els, but continually to be commaunded.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Well, then withdraw your selues, till I haue further considered of this matter.
Now we will see how Apelles goeth forward: I doubt me that nature hath ouercom arte, and her countenance his cunning.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: You loue, and therefore think any thing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But not so farre in loue with Campaspe, as with Bucephalus, if occasion serue either of conflicte or of conquest.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Occasion cannot want, if wil doe not. Behold all Persia swelling in the pride of their owne power, the Scithians carelesse what courage or fortune canne doe: the Egyptians dreaminge in the southsayinges of theyr Augures, and gaping ouer the sinoak of their beastes intralles. All these Alexander are to bee subdued, if that world be not slipped out of your head, which you haue sworne to conquer with that hand.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I confesse the labours fit for Alexander, and yet recreation necessary among so manye assaultes, bloudie woundes, intollerable troubles: giue mee leaue a litle, if not to sitte, yet to breath. And doubt not but Alexander can when he wil throw affections as farre from him, as he can cowardise. But behold Diogenes talking with one at his tub.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: One pennie Diogenes, I am a Cynick.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: He made thee a begger, that first gaue thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: Why, if thou wilte giue nothinge, no bodye wil giue thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I want nothing, till the springs dry, & the earth perish.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: I gather for the Gods.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I care not for those gods, which want money.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: Thou art a right Cynicke, that wyll gyue nothing.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thou art not, that wil beg anything.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: Alexander, kinge Alexander, giue a poore Cynick a groat.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is not for a king to giue a groat.

sp.speaker: Crysus
sp.p: Then giue me a talent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It is not for a begger to aske a talent. Awaye. Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Now Gentlewomanne, doth not your bewtie
put the painter to his trump?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Yes my lord, seeing so disordered a countenance, he feareth he shall, shadow a deformed counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Would he could colour the life with the feature. And me thinketh Apelles, were you as cunning as report saith you are, you may paint flowers aswell with sweete smels, as fresh colours, obseruing in your mixture suche things as should draw neere to their sauours.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your maiestie must know, it is no lesse harde to paint sauours then vertues, colours can neither speake nor think.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Where do you first begin, when you draw anye picture?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: The proportion of the face in iust compasse, as I can.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I would begin with the eie, as a light to all the rest.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: If you wil paint, as you are a king, your Maiesty, maye beginne wher you please, but as you wold be a painter, you must begin with the face.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Aurelius would in one houre colour foure faces.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I meruaile in half an houre he did not foure.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, is it so easie?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: No, but he doth it so homely.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: When wil you finish Campaspe?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Neuer finishe: for alwaies in absolute bewtie there is somwhat aboue arte.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why shoulde not I by labour bee as cunning as Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: God shield you should haue cause to be so cunning as Apelles.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Me thinketh four colours are sufficient to shadow any countenance, & so it was in the time of Phydias.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p:
Then had men fewer fancies, & women not so many fauors. For now, if the haire of her eie browes be black,
yet must the heare of her head be yellowe: the attire of her head must be different from the habite of her body, els would the picture seeme like the blason of auncient Armorie, not like the sweete delight of new found amiablenes. For as in garden knottes diuersitie of odours make a more sweete sauour, or as in musicke diuers stringes cause a more delicate consent, so in painting, the more colours, the better counterfeit, obseruing blacke for a ground, and the rest for grace.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Lend me thy pensil Apelles, I wil paint, and thou shalt iudge.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The coale breakes.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You leane too hard.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now it blackes not.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You leane too soft.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is awry.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your eie goeth not with your hand.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now it is worse.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Your hand goeth not with your minde.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay, if all be too hard or soft, so many rules and regardes, that ones hand ones eie, ones mind muste all draw together, I had rather be setting of a battell, then blotting of a bourd. But how haue I done here?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Like a king.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I think so: but nothing more vnlike a Paynter. Wel Apelles, Campaspe is finished as I wish, dismisse her, & bring presently her counterfeit after me.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I wil.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now Hephestion, doth not this matter cotton as I would, Campaspe looketh pleasantly, liberty wil encrease her bewtie, and my loue shal aduaunce her honour.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: I wil not contrary your maiestie, for time must weare out that loue hath wroughte, and reason weane what appetite noursed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
How stately she passeth bye, yet howe soberlie, a
sweete consent in her countenance with a chast disdain, desire mingled with coynesse, and I cannot tell howe to tearme it, a curst yeelding modestie.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Let her passe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: So shee shall for the fairest on the earth.

sp.speaker: Psyllus.
sp.p: I shalbe hanged for tarying so long.

sp.speaker: Manes.
sp.p: I pray God my maister bee not flowne before I come.

sp.speaker: Psyllus.
sp.p: Away Manes, my maister doth come.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Where haue you bin all this while?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: No where but heere.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Who was here sithence my comming?

sp.speaker: Psil.
sp.p: No body.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Vngratious wag, I perceiue you haue beene a loytering, was Alexander no body?

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: He was a king, I meant no meane body.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I wyll cogell your bodye for it, and then wyll I saye it was no bodye, because it was no honest body. Away in.

Vnfortunate Apelles, and therefore vnfortunate, beecause Apelles. Hast thou by drawing her bewtie brought to passe that thou canst scarse draw thine own breath? And by so muche the more hast thou encreased thy care, by how much the more thou hast shewed thy cunning: was it not sufficient to behold the fire, and warme thee, but with Satyrus thou must kisse the fire and burne thee? O Campaspe, Campaspe, arte must yeelde to nature, reason to appetite, wisdom to affection, Could Pigmalion entreate
by prayer to haue his Iuory turned into flesh? and cannot Apelles obtaine by plaints to haue the picture of his loue chaunged to life? Is painting so farre inferiour to caruing? or doest thou Venus more delight to be hewed with Chizels, then shadowed with colours? what Pigmalion, or what Pyrgoteles, or what Lysippus is hee, that euer made thy face so faire, or spread thy fame so farre as I? vnlesse Venus, in this thou enuiest mine arte, that in colouring my sweete Campaspe, I haue left no place by cunning to make thee so amiable. But alas, shee is the paramour to a prince. Alexander the Monarch of the earth hath both her body and affection. For what is it that kinges cannot obtaine by prayers, threates and promises? Will not she think it better to sit vnder a cloth of estate like a queene, then in a poore shoppe like a huswife? and esteeme it sweeter to be the concubine of the Lord of the world, then spouse to a painter in Athens? Yes, yes Apelles, thou maist swimme against the streame with the Crab, and feede againste the winde with the deere, and pecke against the steele with the Cockatrice: starres are to be looked at, not reached at. Princes to be yelded vnto, not contended with, Campaspe to bee honoured, not obteined, to be painted, not possessed of thee: O fair face, O vnhappy hand, & why didst thou draw it so faire a face? O bewtifull countenaunce, the expresse image of Venus, but somwhat fresher: the only pattern of that eternitie which Iupiter dreaming of asleep, could not conceiue agayne waking. Blush Venus, for I am ashamed to end thee. Now must I paint things vnpossible for mine arte, but agreeable with my affections: deepe and hollowe sighes, sadde and melancholye thoughtes, woundes and slaughters of conceites, a life posting to death, a death galloping from life, a wauering constancie, an vnsetled resolution, and what not, Apelles? And what but Apelles? But as they that are shaken with a feuer are to bee warmed with clothes, not groanes, and as he that melteth in
a consumption is to be recured by Colices, not conceits: so the feeding canker of my care, the neuer dying worm of my heart, is to be killed by counsel, not cries, by applying of remedies, not by replying of reasons. And sith in cases desperat there must be vsed medicines that are extreame, I will hazard that litle life that is left, to restore the greater part that is lost, and this shalbe my first practise: for wit must worke, where authoritie is not. Assoone as Alexander hath viewed this portraiture, I will by deuise giue it a blemishe, that by that meanes shee maye come againe to my shop, and then as good it were to vtter my loue, and die with deniall, as conceale it and liue in despaire.

div.head: Actus quartus, Schaena prima.
div.stage: Solinus, Psyllus, Granichus, Manes, Diogenes, Populus.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: This is the place, the day, the time, that Diogenes hath appointed to flye.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: I wil not loose the flight of so fair a foule as Diogenes is, though my maister cogel my no bodye, as he threatned.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: What Psyllus, will the beaste wag his winges to day?

sp.speaker: Psyl.
sp.p: We shal heare: for here commeth Manes: Manes will it be?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Be, he were best be as cunning as a Bee, 'or else shortly he will not be at all.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: How is he furnished to flye, hath he feathers?

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Thou art an asse, Capons, Geese and Owles haue feathers. He hath found Dedalus old waxen wings, and hath beene peecing them this moneth, he is so broad in the shoulders. O you shal see him cut the aire euen like a Tortoys.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: Methinks so wise a man should not be so mad, his body must needes be too heauy.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Why, he hath eaten nothing this seuennight but corke and feathers.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Tutch him Manes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: He is so light that he can scarse keepe him from flying at midnight.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: See they beginne to flocke, and behold my maister bustels himself to flye.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p:
Yee wicked and bewitched Athenians, whose bodies make the earth to groane, and whose breathes infect the aire with stench. Come ye to see Diogenes flye? Diogenes commeth to see you sinke: yee call me dog, so I am, for I long to gnawe the boanes in your skins. Yee tearme mean hater of menne: no, I am a hater of your māers. Your liues dissolute, not fearing death, wil proue your deaths desperate, not hoping for life. What do you els in Athens but sleepe in the daye, and surfeite in the night: back Gods in the morning with pride, in the euening belly Gods with gluttony. You flatter kings, & call them Gods, speak trueth of your selues, and confesse you are deuils. From the Bee you haue taken not the honey, but the wax to make your religion, framing it to the time, not to the trueth. Your filthy lust you colour vnder a courtly colour of loue, iniuries abroad vnder the title of pollicies at home, & secrete malice creepeth vnder the name of publike iustice. You haue caused Alexander to dry vp springs and plant vines, to sow roket and weede endiffe, to sheare sheepe, and shrine foxes. All conscience is sealed at Athens. Swearing commeth of a hot mettle: lying of a quick wit: flattery of a flowing tong, vndecent talk of a mery disposition. Al things are lawful at Athens. Either you think there are no Gods, or I must think yee are no men. You build as though you shoulde liue for euer, and surfeit as though you should die tomorow.
None teacheth true Phylosophy but Aristotle, beecause he was the kinges schoolemaister. O times, O menne, O corruption in manners. Remember that greene grasse must turne to dry hay. When you sleep, you are not sure to wake, and when you rise not certeine to lye downe. Looke you neuer so hye, your heads must lye leuel with your feet. Thus haue I flown ouer your disordered liues, and if you will not amende your manners, I will studie to flye further from you, that I may be neerer to honestie.

sp.speaker: Soli.
sp.p: Thou rauest Diogenes, for thy life is different from thy woordes. Did not, I see thee come out of a brothel house? was it not a shame?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It was no shame to goe out, but a shame to goe in.

sp.speaker: Grant.
sp.p: It were a good deede Manes, to beate thy maister.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: You were as good eate my maister.

sp.speaker: One of the people.
sp.p: Hast thou made vs all fooles, and wile thou not flye?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I tell thee, vnlesse thou be honest, I wil fly.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: Dog, dog, take a boane.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thy father neede fear no dogs, but dogs thy father.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: We wil tel Alexander, that thou reproouest him behind his back.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And I wil tell him, that you flatter him beefore his face.

sp.speaker: People
sp.p: We wil cause all the boies in the streete to hisse at thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: In deede I think the Athenians haue their children redy for any vice, because they be Athenians.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Why maister, meane you not to flye?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No Manes, not without wings.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: Euery body wil account you a lyar.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No, I warrant you: for I will alwayes say the Athenians are mischieuous.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: I care not, it was sport ynough for me to see these old huddles hit home.

sp.speaker: Gran.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Psyllus
sp.p: Come, let vs goe, and hereafter when I meane to raise vpon any body openly, it shall be giuen out, I will flye.

sp.speaker: Campaspe sola.
sp.p: Campaspe, it is hard to iudge whether thy choice be more vnwise, or thy chaunce vnfortunate. Doest thou preferre, but stay, vtter not that in woords, which maketh thine eares to glow with thoughtes. Tush better thy tongue wagge, then thy heart breake. Hath a painter crept further into thy mind then a prince? Apelles then Alexander? Fond wench, the basenes of thy mind bewraies the meannesse of thy birth. But alas, affection is a fire, which kindleth aswell in the bramble as in the oak, and catcheth hold where it first lighteth, not where it may best burne, Larkes that mount aloft in the ayre, build their neastes below in the earth, and women that cast their eies vpon kinges, may place their hearts vpon vassals. A needle will become thy fingers better then a lute, and a distaffe is fitter for thy hand then a scepter. Auntes liue safely, till they haue gotten winges, and Iuniper is not blowne vp, till it hath gotten an high top. The mean estate is without care as long as it continueth without pride. But here commeth Apelles, in whom I would there were the like affection.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, the misfortune I had with your picture, will put you to some paines, to sitte againe to be painted.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: It is small paines for me to sit still, but infinit for you to draw still.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: No Madame, to painte Venus was a pleasure, but to shadowe the sweet face of Campaspe it is a heauen.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: If your tongue were made of the same flesh that your heart is, your wordes woulde be as your thoughts are: but such a common thing it is amongst you to commend, that oftentimes for fashion sake you call them bewtifull, whom you know blacke.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: What might men doe to be beleeued?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Whet their tongues on their hearts.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: So they doe, and speake as they think.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I would they did.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I would they did not.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Why, would you haue them dissemble?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Not in loue, but theyr loue. But will you giue me leaue to ask you a question without offence?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: So that you will aunswere me an other without excuse.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Whom do you loue best in the world?

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: He that made me last in the world.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: That was a God.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: I had thought it had beene a man: but whome do you honour most Apelles?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: The thing that is likest you Campaspe.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: My picture?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I dare not venture vpon your person. But come, let vs go in: for Alexander will thinke it longe till we returne.

sp.speaker: Clytus
sp.p:
We heare nothing of our Embassage, a colour
belike to bleare our eies, or ticle our eares, or inflame our heartes. But what doth Alexander in the meane season, but vse for Tantara, Sol. Fa. La. for his harde couch, downe beddes, for his handfull of water, his standinge Cup of wine?

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: Clytus, I mislike this new delicacie and pleasing peace: for what els do we see now then a kind of softnes in euery mans minde, Bees to make their hiues in soldiers helmets, our steedes furnished with foote clothes of golde, insteede of saddles of steele: More time to bee required to scowre the rust of our weapons, then there was woont to be in subdewing the countries of our enemies. Sithence Alexander fell from his harde armour to his softe robes, beholde the face of his court, youthes that were woont to carry deuises of victory in their shieldes, engraue now posies of loue in their ringes: they that were accustomed on trotting horses to charge the enemie with a launce, now in easie coche ride vp & downe to court Ladies: in steede of sworde and target to hazard their liues, vse penne and paper to paint their loues. Yea, such a feare and faintnes is growne in courte, that they wish rather to heare the blowing of a horne to hunt, then the sound of a trumpet to fight? O Phillip, wert thou aliue to see this alteration, thy men turned to women, thy soldiers to louers, gloues worne in veluet, caps in steede of plumes in grauen helmets, thou wouldest either dye among them for sorow, or confound them for anger.

sp.speaker: Clitus
sp.p: Cease Permenio, least in speaking what becommeth thee not, thou feele what liketh thee not: trueth is neuer without a scratcht face, whose tongue although it cannot be cut out, yet must it be tied vp.

sp.speaker: Parme.
sp.p: It greeueth me not a litle for Hephestion, whoe thristeth for honour, not ease, but such is his fortune & neerenesse in friendship to Alexander, that he must lay a pillowe vnder his head, when he would put a targette in his hand.
But let vs draw in, to see how well it beecomes them to tread the measures in a daunce, that were wont to set the order for a march.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I haue now Campaspe almost made an end.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: You told me Apelles, you would neuer end.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Neuer end my loue: for it shal be eternal.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: That is, neither to haue beginning nor ending.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: You are disposed to mistake, I hope you do not mistrust.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: What will you saye, if Alexander perceiue your loue?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: I will say, it is no treason to loue.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: But how if he will not suffer thee to see my person?

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Then will I gase continually on thy picture.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: That will not feede thy heart.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Yet shall it fill mine eie: beesides the sweete thoughtes, the sure hopes, thy protested faith, will cause me to embrace thy shadow continuallye in mine armes, of the which by stronge imagination I will make a substaunce.

sp.speaker: Camp.
sp.p: Wel, I must be gon: but this assure your self, that I had rather be in thy shop grinding colours, then in Alexanders court, following higher fortunes.

Foolish wench, what hast thou done? that alas which cannot be vndone, and therefore I feare me vndone. But content is such a life, I care not for aboundance. O Apelles,
thy loue commeth from the hearte, but Alexanders from the mouth. The loue of Kynges is lyke the blowinge of windes, whiche whistle sometimes gently amonge the leaues, and straight waies turne the trees vp by the rootes, or fire which warmeth a farre off, and burneth neere hand, or the sea, which maketh men hoyse their sayles in a flattering calme, and to cut their mastes in a rough storme. They place affection by times, by pollicie, by appointment, if they frowne, who dares call them vnconstant, if bewray secretes, who wil tearme them vntrue, if fall to other loues, who trembles not, if he call them vnfaithfull. In kinges there can be no loue, but to Queenes: for as neere must they meete in maiestie, as they doe in affection. It is requisite to stande aloofe from kings loue, loue, and lightening.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: Now Apelles, gather thy wittes together: Campaspe is no lesse wise then faire, thy selfe must be no lesse cunning then faithfull. It is no small matter to be riuall with Alexander.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Apelles, you must come away quicklye with the picture, the king thinketh that nowe you haue painted it, you play with it.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: If I would playe with pictures, I haue enough at home.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: None perhaps you like so well.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It may be I haue painted none so well.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I haue knowne many fairer faces.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: And I many better boies.

div.head: Actus quintus, Shaena prima.
div.stage: Diogenes, Syluius, Perim, Milo Irico, Manes.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: I haue brought my sons Diogenes, to bee taught of thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: What can thy sonnes doe?

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: You shall see their qualities: Daunce sirha.

div.p: How like you this? doth he well?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The better, the worser.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: The musicke very good.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: The Musitions very badde, who onelye studie to haue their stringes in tune, neuer framing their manners to order.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Now shall you see the other: tumble sirha.

div.p: How like you this? why do you laugh?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To see a wagge, that was born to break his neck by destinie, to practise it by arte.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: This dogge will bite me, I wil not be with him.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Feare not boy, dogges eate no thistles.

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: I meruaile what dog thou art, if thou be a dog.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: When I am hungry, a mastiue, and when my belly is full, a spaniell.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Doest thou beleeue that there are any gods, that thou art so dogged?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I must needs beleeue there are Gods: for I think thee an enemie to them.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Beecause thou hast taught one of thy sonnes to rule his legges, and not to follow learning, the other to bend his body euery way, and his minde no way.

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: Thou doest nothing but snarle, and barke like a dogge.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: It is the next way to driue away a theefe.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Now shall you heare the third, who signes like a Nightingall.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I care not: for I haue heard a Nightingall sing her self.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Sing sirha.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Loe Diogenes, I am sure thou canst not doe so much.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But there is neuer a Thrush but can.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: What hast thou taught Manes thy man?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: To be as vnlike as may be thy sonnes.

sp.speaker: Manes
sp.p: He hath taught me to fast, lye hard, and runne away.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Howe saiest thou Perim, wilte thou bee with him?

sp.speaker: Perim.
sp.p: I, so he will teach me first to runne away.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Thou needest not be taught, thy legs are so nimble.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Howe sayest thou Milo wilte thou bee with him?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nay, hold your peace, he shall not.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: There is not roome enough for him and mee both to tumble in one tub.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Well Diogenes, I perceiue my sonnes brook not thy manners.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I thought no lesse, when they knewe my vertues.

sp.speaker: Sylui.
sp.p: Farewell Diogenes, thou neededst not haue scraped rootes, if thou woldest haue followed Alexander.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Nor thou haue followed Alexander, if thou hadst scraped rootes.

I feare me Apelles, that thine eies haue blabbed that, which thy tongue durste not. What little regarde hadst thou, whilest Alexander viewed the counterfeite of Campaspe, thou stoodest gazing on her countenaunce? If hee espy or but suspect, thou must needes twise perishe with his hate, and thine owne loue. Thy pale lookes, when he blushed, thy sadde countenaunce, when hee smyled, thy sighes, when he questioned, may breede in him a ielosie, perchaunce a frenzey. O loue, I neuer beefore knewe what thou wert, and nowe haste thou made mee that I know not what my self am? Onely this I knowe, that I must endure intollerable passions, for vnknowne pleasures. Dispute not the cause wretch, but yeelde to it: for better it is to melt with desire, then wrastle with loue. Cast thy selfe on thy carefull bedde, be content to lyue vnknown, and die vnfounde. O Campaspe, I haue painted thee in my hearte, paynted? nay, contrarye to mine arte, imprinted, and that in suche deepe Characters, that nothing can rase it out, vnlesse it rubbe thy hearte out.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It shal go hard, but this peace shal bring vs some pleasure.

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Downe with armes, and vp with legges, this is a world for the nonce.

sp.speaker: Lays
sp.p: Sweete youthes, if you knew what it were to saue your sweete bloud, you would not so foolishly go about to spend it. What delight can there be in gasshinge, to make foule scarres in faire faces, & crooked maimes in streight legges? as though men being borne goodlye by nature, would of purpose become deformed by follye, and all forsooth for a new found tearme, called valiant, a worde which breedeth more quarrelles then the sense can commendation.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It is true Lays, a featherbed hath no fellow, good drinke makes good bloud, and shal pelting wordes spill it?

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: I meane to enjoy the world, and to draw out my life at the wiredrawers, not to curtall it off at the cuttelers.

sp.speaker: Lays
sp.p: You may talke of warre, speake bigge, conquer worldes with great wordes: but stay at home, where in steede of Alarums you shall haue daunces, for hot battelles with fierce menne, gentle skirmishes with faire womenne. These pewter coates canne neuer sitte so well as satten dublets. Beleeue mee, you cannot conceiue the pleasure of peace, vnlesse you despise the rudenes of warre.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: It is so. But see Diogenes prying ouer his tubbe: Diogenes, what saiest thou to such a morsel?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I say, I would spit it out of my mouth, because it should not poyson my stomacke.

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Thou speakest as thou arte, 'it is no meate for dogges.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: I am a dogge, and Phylosophy rates mee from carion.

sp.speaker: Lays
sp.p: Vnciuill wretch, whose manners are aunswerable to thy callynge, the tyme was thou wouldest haue hadde my companie, had it not beene, as thou saidst too deare.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p:
I remember there was a thing, that I repented
me of, and now thou haste told it, indeede it was too deare of nothing, and thou deare to no bodye.

sp.speaker: Lays
sp.p: Downe villaine, or I wil haue thy head broken?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Will you couch?

sp.speaker: Phry.
sp.p: Auaunt curre: Come sweete Lays, let vs goe to some place, and possesse peace. But first let vs sing, there is more pleasure in tuning of a voyce, then in a vollye of shotte.

sp.speaker: Milec.
sp.p: Now let vs make haste, least Alexander finde vs here.

div.head: Actus quintus, Schaena quarta.
div.stage: Alexander. Hephestion, Page, Diogenes, Apelles, Campaspe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Mee thinketh Hephestion you are more melancholy then you were accustomed; but I perceiue it is all for Alexander. You can neither brooke this peace, nor my pleasure, be of good cheare, though I winke, I sleepe not.

sp.speaker: Hephest.
sp.p: Melancholy I am not, nor well content: for I know not how there is such a ruste crept into my bones with this long ease, that I feare I shall not scowre it out with infinite labours.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, yes, if all the trauailes of conquering the world will set either thy body or mine in tune, wee will vndertake them. But what think you of Apelles? Did yee euer see any so perplexed? Hee neither aunswered directly to any question, nor looked stedfastly vppon anye thing. I hold my life the painter is in loue.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p:
It may be: for commonly we see it incident in artificers to be inamoured of their own workes, as Archidamus of his woodden doue, Pygmalion, of his iuorie
Image, Arachne of his wodden swan, especially painters, who playing with their own conceites, now coueting to draw a glauncing eie, then a rolling, now a wincking; stil mending it, neuer ending it, till they bee caught with it, and then poore soules they kisse the colours with their lippes, with which before they were loth to tainte theyr fingers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I wil finde it out. Page, goe speedelye for Apelles, will him to come hether, and when you see vs earnestly in talke, sodenly cry out, Apelles shoppe is on fire.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: It shal be done.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Forget not your lesson

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: I meruaile what your deuice shalbe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The euent shall proue.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: I pittie the poore painter, if he be in loue.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pittie him not, I pray thee, that seuere grauity set aside, what do you think of loue?

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: As the Macedonians doe of their Hearbe Beet, which looking yellow in the ground; and blacke in the hand, thinke it better seene then toucht.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But what do you imagine it to be.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: A word by superstition thought a God, by vse turned to an humour, by self will made a flattering madnesse.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You are too hard harted to think so of loue. Let vs go to Diogenes. Diogenes, thou maist think it somwhat, that Alexander commeth to thee againe so soone

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: If you come to learn, you could not come soone enough, if to laugh, you be come too soone.

sp.speaker: Hephe.
sp.p: It would better become thee to be more curteous, and frame thy self to please.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And you better to be lesse, if you durst displease.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What dost thou think of the time we haue here?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That we haue lit be; and lose much.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If one be sick, what wouldest thou haue him do?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Be sure that he make not his Phisition his hiere.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: If thou mightest haue thy wil, how much ground would content thee?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: As much as you in the ende must bee contented withall.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What, a world?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: No, the length of my body.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hephestion, shal I be a litle pleasaunt with him?

sp.speaker: Heph.
sp.p: You may: but he wil be very peruerse with you.

sp.speaker: Apel.
sp.p: It skilleth not, I cannot be angry with him. Diogenes, I pray thee, what dost thou think of loue?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: A litle worser then I can of hate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Because it is better to hate the thinges, which make to loue, then to loue the things, which giue occasion of hate.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, be not women the best creatures in the world?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Next men and Bees.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What dost thou dislike chiefly in a woman?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: One thing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: That she is a woman.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In mine opinion thou wert neuer born of a woman, that thou thinkest so hardly of women. But not commeth Apelles, who I am sure is as far from thy thoghts, as thou art from his cunning. Diogenes, I wil haue thy cabin remoued nerer to my court, because I wil be a philosopher

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And when you haue done so, I pray you remoue your court further from my cabinne, because I wil not be a courtier.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But here commeth Apelles. Apelles, what peece of work haue you now in hand?

sp.speaker: Apel.
